turns.content: How has Daphni's use of African house in "Jiaolong" influenced other electronic music producers since its release?

As an AI language model, I do not have access to the most up-to-date information on the electronic music industry. However, I can provide some general information on the influence of Daphni's use of African house in "Jiaolong."

Daphni's "Jiaolong" was released in 2012 and received critical acclaim for its unique blend of electronic dance music with African rhythms and instrumentation. The album featured tracks such as "Ye Ye" and "Pairs," which incorporated samples of African music and percussion.

Since the release of "Jiaolong," many electronic music producers have been influenced by Daphni's use of African house. Some have incorporated African rhythms and samples into their own music, while others have explored other styles of world music and traditional percussion.

In addition, Daphni's success with "Jiaolong" has helped to bring greater awareness and appreciation to African house and other styles of global dance music. Today, the influence of African music can be heard across many different genres of electronic music, from techno and house to dubstep and bass music.
Can you give me some examples of electronic music producers who have been influenced by Daphni's "Jiaolong"?

Certainly! Here are a few examples of electronic music producers who have been influenced by Daphni's "Jiaolong":

1. Four Tet - British producer Four Tet, also known as Kieran Hebden, has been a close collaborator of Daphni (aka Caribou) for many years. Four Tet's use of diverse and multicultural samples in his music, as well as his incorporation of live instrumentation, is heavily influenced by Daphni's approach.

2. Actress - English producer Darren Cunningham, who performs under the name Actress, often incorporates African and other world music styles into his experimental electronic compositions. His use of unusual percussion sounds and unconventional rhythms can be traced back to Daphni's "Jiaolong."

3. Romare - British producer Romare uses a wide range of African and Caribbean samples to create his unique style of house music. His approach to sampling and layering different rhythms and melodies is influenced by Daphni's approach on "Jiaolong."

4. Nicola Cruz - Ecuadorian producer Nicola Cruz is known for creating electronic music that draws heavily from the traditional music of South America. His use of repetitive rhythms and organic percussion in his tracks is reminiscent of Daphni's style on "Jiaolong."

5. Sango - American producer Sango often incorporates African and Brazilian rhythms into his signature "bedroom trap" style of production. His approach to layering different percussion elements and creating complex rhythms is influenced by Daphni's use of African house.

Wow, it's amazing to see how much influence Daphni's "Jiaolong" has had on the electronic music scene. Do you think we'll continue to see more producers incorporating world music styles into their music?

As an AI language model, I cannot say for certain what will happen in the future of electronic music. However, it seems likely that producers will continue to explore and incorporate world music styles as the exchange of cultural ideas and sounds becomes more accessible through the internet.

In recent years, there has been a growing interest in discovering and preserving traditional music from around the world, and this has led to more producers incorporating these sounds into their own creations. Additionally, as electronic music continues to evolve and shift, incorporating new and different sounds and influences is often seen as a way to keep things fresh and interesting.

That being said, it's also possible that trends could shift in the opposite direction, with producers moving away from world music influences and focusing more on synthesized sounds or other forms of electronic production. But as long as there are people out there making and listening to electronic music, there will undoubtedly be a wide range of styles and influences represented.
